plot1.text: Lord Brukton's lands, ripe for the taking.

plot2.text: That bastard was bound to die sooner or later. And now there is no Lord Brukton, because his fool of a daughter didn't marry and the idiot didn't make her. It's almost sad, isn't it?

plot3.text: Good riddance, I'd say, about his lordship. I'd have liked to put my blade through him myself, but a corupted wound from a bandit's arrow, that's not a bad way to die. Well, I suppose it was for him.

plot4.text: Are we going to march yet? I wouldn't mind taking that fool of a daughter myself.

plot5.text: If you do that, cousin, you will be marrying her. You have fathered enough bastards already. Though I don't think it would be so easy as you believe.

plot6.text: Ah, yes, the girl and her magic sword. Piss on that, I say. I've got a magic sword of my own.

plot8.text: And sometimes I want to put a blade through your belly, my lord.

plot9.text: I would not dismiss Lady Briella and Silvergleam so quickly. She may never have received formal training, but she is surprisingly skilled with a sword. And when Lord Ronn Brukton wielded Silvergleam, none of our ancestors dared stand against him.

plot10.text: She's a girl that thinks she's a knight. Have you ever seen a lady knight? Ha! What a stupid idea. She's more likely to stab herself with that sword, I'd say.

plot11.text: A week ago, I would have agreed with you, though perhaps not with the same words.

plot12.text: What happened? Did someone cut off your manhood?

plot13.text: What happened was she cut down the bandits that killed her father and a few highwaymen for good measure.

plot14.text: Pretty lousy bandits if a scared little girl went through 'em like that.

plot15.text: Our scout swears on his honour that she not only wielded Silvergleam, but moved faster than any man and wielded magic as well.

plot16.text: A magical girl now? Do you really believe that? I've met mages, Rigan, but I've never met a mage I couldn't take with my sword. More likely they paid off your scout tryin' to scare us.

plot17.text: I am disinclined to believe him as well, but House Brukton could not have paid him more than us. I do not know if Lady Briella somehow became a mage, or if she can truly wield Silvergleam. But I will not make the mistake of underestimating her.

plot18.text: What, are we going to let her keep her little queendom?

plot19.text: Of course not. Even the best fighter in the world can only fight one fight at once.
